results.title: Season of change could end with ring for Thomas
results.body:
USA TODAY Sports' Tom Pelissero with three reasons the Denver Broncos can win Super Bowl. USA TODAY Sports

CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

SANTA CLARA, Calif. - In so many ways, this has been the greatest year of Demaryius Thomas' life.

He received a $70 million contract from the Denver Broncos, a well-earned pay raise after three Pro Bowl seasons in his first five years in the NFL, and the life-changing news that came in July, when his mother, Katina Smith, was released after more than 15 years in prison.

But such great joys weren't without their pitfalls.

The huge contract came with massive expectations, even as the Broncos transformed from a pass-heavy offense to a run-first scheme that would take a toll on his stats. And his mother's return home for the first time since Thomas was 11 meant major responsibilities for her now-grown son, even if he could not travel to Georgia to see her.

Smith went from a Tallahassee, Fla., prison to a Georgia halfway house in July. Then in November, she was released to live fully on her own for the first time since 1999. She needed Thomas' help with getting settled and adjusted, and he grew accustomed to talking to her multiple times a day.

But the hardest part for Thomas was knowing that even though Smith was no longer incarcerated, he was still so far away from her, because of his rigorous NFL schedule and rules that barred her from traveling until after the New Year.

"That was the biggest thing, just not seeing her," Thomas said Tuesday. "That bothered me a little bit."

They finally reunited for the Broncos' divisional playoff game against the Pittsburgh Steelers last month. Smith flew to Denver and watched her son play in person for the first time. She wore a personalized No. 88 jersey and sat in a suite. She watched the AFC Championship Game from home in Georgia, but she'll be in Santa Clara on Sunday for the Super Bowl, Thomas said.

USA TODAY

All signs point to Brock Osweiler as Broncos' starting quarterback for 2016

He insists it's not a distraction, nor is it any extra motivation. It's just exciting, he said, to know that she'll be there, and that she'll be so happy.

And he's happy now, too, and seemingly relieved that the pressure of his mother's first trip is over. Perhaps that will be a good sign as he heads into Super Bowl 50 against the Carolina Panthers.

The off-field stress he was dealing with in November and December coincided with a rough stretch of games, with just one game with double-digit catches and one with more than 100 yards over the Broncos' final 10 regular-season contests. He struggled with drops - he had at least nine this season - and finished the year with 1,304 receiving yards and six touchdowns, both significant decreases from his 2014 output.

He had just two catches for 12 yards in the AFC Championship Game against the New England Patriots.

USA TODAY

Brennan: What will be Peyton Manning's legacy after Super Bowl 50?

"He does get a lot of criticism about the drops, but it's not fair. Everybody forgets he had 1,300 yards this year. It's like come on, man. He got 1,300; leave the man alone," wide receiver Emmanuel Sanders said. "OK, he might have eight drops, but ask any organization in the National Football League if they'll take Demaryius Thomas and they'll say yes, bring him over here. I'm just happy to be a part of it, happy to be his teammate."

But Thomas played well in the Broncos' previous Super Bowl appearance. He may have been the only Broncos offensive player to have a good game against the Seattle Seahawks two years ago, with a Super Bowl record 13 catches for 118 yards and a touchdown in the 43-8 loss.

Matching those numbers against the Panthers could prove difficult if Thomas draws the matchup against Carolina's No. 1 cornerback Josh Norman. But Thomas might have advantages that other receivers who have struggled against Norman this year do not. He's quiet on the field, with a low-key demeanor that should prevent Norman from getting into his head like happened with the Giants' Odell Beckham Jr., and he's got a standout receiver opposite him in Sanders.

Several times this year, including in the AFC Championship Game, Sanders has been the one who has drawn the top opposing cornerback.

"I think that a lot of teams put their No. 1 corner on me and then put the No. 2 on Demaryius and give that No. 1 help over the top. Which is smart, but sometimes I end up beating that No. 1 corner," Sanders said, laughing. "Norman is a great corner, but Demaryius and I have been facing great corners all year."

***

Follow Lindsay H. Jones on Twitter @bylindsayhjones

results.title: Breaking down 37 ridiculous Super Bowl prop bets
results.body:
Online sportsbook Bovada.lv has once again compiled a list of amausing Super Bowl specials. Here are the most notable ones along with our expert analysis. If you're in a place where betting on the Super Bowl is illegal, this is all purely theoretical, of course ...

1. Will Peyton Manning announce his retirement in the postgame interview?

Yes +500 (5/1)

No -1000 (1/10)

Verdict: YES. He probably won't, but it would be such a glorious way to go out.

2. Will Peyton Manning be seen crying at any point during the entire Broadcast?

Yes +600 (6/1)

No -1200 (1/12)

Verdict: YES. Let the tears flow, Peyton.

3. How many times will "dab" or "dabbing" be said by the announcers during the Broadcast?

Over 2 (EVEN, 1/1)

Under 2 (-140, 5/7)

Verdict: UNDER. Over two dabs just seems a bit repetitive, doesn't it?

4. How many times will Cam Newton do the Open Shirt Superman motion during the game?

Over 2.5 (EVEN, 1/1)

Under 2.5 (-140, 5/7)

Verdict: OVER. It's predicated on the Panthers winning, but come on: it's his signature.

5. If Steph Curry is shown on TV during the Broadcast what will he be wearing?

Personalized Carolina Steph Curry Jersey 1/1

No Jersey 2/1

Cam Newton Jersey 3/1

Any Other Carolina Jersey 5/1

Verdict: PERSONALIZED JERSEY. Too easy.

6. Will Mike Carey be wrong about a challenge?

Yes +110 (11/10)

No -150 (2/3)

Verdict: NO. Mike Carey isn't actually that bad.

7. Will there be an earthquake during the game?

Yes 10/1

Verdict: NO. Don't give yourself a reason to root for earthquakes.

8. Will the Panthers player who scores their first TD give the football to a Boy or Girl?

Boy -200 (1/2)

Girl +150 (3/2)

Verdict: BOY. The safe bet because there'll probably be more of them there.

9. How many times will the Golden Gate Bridge be shown during the Broadcast?

Over 0.5 -300 (1/3)

Under 0.5 +200 (2/1)

Verdict: OVER. Free (theoretical) money.

10. How many times will "John Fox" be said during the Broadcast?

Over 1 (-140, 5/7)

Under 1 (EVEN, 1/1)

Verdict: OVER. Potential payoff of the under doesn't make that bet worth it.

11. How many times will Archie Manning be shown on TV during the Broadcast?

Over 1.5 EVEN (1/1)

Under 1.5 -140 (5/7)

Verdict: OVER. Once is a lock, it's the extra .5 that makes it a swing vote.

(Derick E. Hingle / USA TODAY Sports)

12. How many times will John Elway be shown on TV during broadcast?

Over 2.5 EVEN (1/1)

Under 2.5 -140 (5/7)

Verdict: UNDER. Three is a lot, especially if the Broncos get behind early and go on to lose.

13. Will the announcers mention that Kubiak was Elway's backup during the broadcast?

Yes +120 (6/5)

No -160 (5/8)

Verdict: YES. That little snippet of information is too tempting.

14. What color will the liquid be that is poured on the winning coach?

Orange 5/4

Blue 3/1

Clear 4/1

Yellow 4/1

Red 6/1

Green 10/1

Purple 10/1

Verdict: BLUE. Decent value here. Blue Gatorade was dumped on Belichick last year, and both teams play in blue.

15. Who will the Super Bowl MVP mention first?

God 2/1

Team 2/1

City/Fans 6/1

Coach 15/2

Family 15/1

Does not Mention Anyone above 9/4

Verdict: FAMILY. Say Cam wins, his son was just born -- 15/1 is a big price in those circumstances.

16. Which song will Coldplay play first during the Halftime show?

Adventure of a Lifetime 2/1

Fix You 7/2

A Sky Full of Stars 9/2

Viva la Vida 5/1

Clocks 15/2

Speed of Sound 9/1

Head Full of Dreams 10/1

Paradise 10/1

Verdict: FIX YOU. "I'm banging Fix You hard; that's free money at 7/2," - FTW Culture Editor Nate Scott.

17. What color will Beyonce's footwear be when she comes on stage for the Halftime show?

Black 3/2

Gold/Brown 5/2

White 11/4

Silver/Grey 19/4

Any Other Color 7/1

Verdict: GOLD/BROWN. That was the predominant color in the music video for Beyonce's recent collaboration with Coldplay.

18. Will "Left Shark" Make an appearance on stage during the Super Bowl Halftime Show?

Yes 15/1

Verdict: NO. Doing that would require the NFL to have a decent sense of humor.

19. How many million viewers will Super Bowl 50 have?

Over/Under 117 million

Verdict: OVER. Was north of a 120 million last year, and now we have Cam vs. Peyton.

20. What will the Nielsen Rating be for Super Bowl 50?

Over/Under 48.5

Verdict: OVER. Did 49.7 last year; let's throw caution to the wind and be bullish.

21. Which Region will have a higher Nielsen Rating?

Denver -140 (5/7)

Charlotte EVEN (1/1)

Verdict: DENVER. This could be Peyton's last chance!?

22. How many wings will Buffalo Wild Wings Sell on Super Bowl Day?

Over/Under 12 million

Verdict: UNDER. Didn't hit that number last year, and it's an awful lot of chicken.

23. Coin Toss

Heads -105 (20/21)

Tails -105 (20/21)

Verdict: TAILS. Tails never fails, obviously.

24. Will the referee redo the Coin Toss?

Yes 20/1

Verdict: NO. Don't be cheeky.

25. Will the team that chooses Heads or Tails in the coin toss be correct?

Yes -105 (20/21)

No -105 (20/21)

Verdict: YES. I mean, I don't know. It's literally betting on a coin flip.

26. Team to win the coin toss

Carolina Panthers -105 (20/21)

Denver Broncos -105 (20/21)

Verdict: PANTHERS. Again, it's a coin flip.

27. Will the team that wins the coin toss win the game?

Yes -105 (20/21)

No -105 (20/21)

Verdict: YES. Why not?

28. Will there be a penalty for excessive celebration?

Yes +250 (5/2)

No -400 (1/4)

Verdict: NO. It's the Super Bowl, they'll let it slide.

29. Will either backup QB take a snap in the game?

Yes +200 (2/1)

No -300 (1/3)

Verdict: NO. It all comes down to Peyton, and I think he'll make it through the game.

30. Cross Sport Props - What will be higher?

Trump % Points in the New Hampshire Primary -200 (1/2)

Total Points scored by the winning Super Bowl team +150 (3/2)

Verdict: TRUMP. He's hovering in the high 30s right now. Even if turnout suffers and his oppoents eat into his lead, not sure either team could catch him.

31. Cross Sport Props - Exact Outcome

Carolina wins Super Bowl - Trump Wins 2016 Presidential Election 13/4

Carolina wins Super Bowl - Cinton Wins 2016 Presidential Election 7/4

Carolina wins Super Bowl - Sanders Wins 2016 Presidential Election 5/1

Denver wins Super Bowl - Trump Wins 2016 Presidential Election 7/1

Denver wins Super Bowl - Clinton Wins 2016 Presidential Election 9/2

Denver wins Super Bowl - Sanders Wins 2016 Presidential Election 10/1

Verdict: CAROLINA-CLINTON. Pundits think Trump and Sanders will struggle to overcome the Republican and Democratic establishments. That leaves Clinton, and if you haven't deduced it by now, I'm picking Carolina to beat Denver.

32. Cross Sport Props - What are the odds the Carolina Panthers win the 2016 Super Bowl and the Golden State Warriors win the 2015-2016 NBA Title?

Yes 2/1

Verdict: YES. It's going to be a good year for Steph Curry.

33. Will Denver win Super Bowl, Peyton Manning Retires, San Antonio wins NBA Championship, Tim Duncan Retires?

Yes 20/1

Verdict: NO. I'm only voting "no" for the sake of consistency; this would be a fun bet to pull for.

34. Cross Sport Props - What will be higher?

DeMarcus Cousins Points and Rebounds Feb. 7th

Cam Newton Rushing Yards

Verdict: COUSINS. Cousins has averaged 27 points with 11 rebounds so far this season, and had 16 points with seven rebounds the last time he played the Celtics (his Feb 7th opponent). Let's say Cousins gets 32-ish combined points/rebounds this time; Cam has been held to under 32 yards seven times this season, and I like Denver's stout rush defence to do it again.

35. Cross Sport Props - What will be higher?

Total Goals in the Montreal vs Carolina NHL game on Feb. 7th

Total Receptions by Greg Olsen

Verdict: OLSEN. Olsen is averaging more than seven receptions a game so far this season and seven on the number this postseason. That'd require a high-scoring game between Montreal and Carolina, who are each averaging about two goals per game so far this season.

36. Cross Sport Props - What will be higher?

Tiger Woods 1st Round score at 2016 Masters

Emmanuel Sanders Receiving Yards

Verdict: SANDERS. This is a joke, right? Tiger almost definitely won't hit a shot at the 2016 Masters because he's injured, so even if Sanders has just one receiving yard, he'll still win.

37. Cross Sport Props - What will be higher?

Arsenal Total Goals on Feb. 7th

Peyton Manning TD Passes

Verdict: ARSENAL. Arsenal will probably win 2-1, but against a smaller team like Bournemouth could score three or four. Can't really see Manning throwing more than two, at the most, touchdown passes.

That's where we stand. Good luck, and may fortune be ever in your favor.

results.title: Super Bowl 50 truly a home game for Broncos tailback and Bay Area native CJ Anderson
results.body:
5 CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

SAN FRANCISCO -- The ritual is always the same. Before C.J. Anderson pulls on his cleats Sunday and prepares to step into the fray of Super Bowl 50, he will spend a moment in silent contemplation of a fallen friend.

For the Denver Broncos running back, returning to the Bay Area means coming home. Anderson grew up in the troubled city of Vallejo, just outside Oakland, and attended Jesse Bethel High School.

That is where he stood watching on the sideline Nov.7, 2004, when his friend and hero Mike Pennerman prepared to hold for an extra point. It was the last play Pennerman, a freakishly talented junior receiver seemingly destined for a big college career and possibly more, would ever make.

USA TODAY

Super Bowl 50 matchups: Broncos RB C.J. Anderson vs. Panthers' front seven

"I remember how great he was. It was unbelievable the skill he had for a high school player," Anderson said. "I know he would have made it. He would have been great in college and made it to the NFL, I'm sure of it. Everyone in the area tries to live in his honor. He is never forgotten."

The snap on that PAT went over Pennerman's head, and he scrambled to collect it, before being piled on by a pack of players from Rodriguez High School. After walking to the sideline, Pennerman, a cousin of 1994 Heisman Trophy winner Rashaan Salaam, complained of feeling "heavy," collapsed and died in hospital the following day as a result of brain injuries.

His death stunned the local community and had a profound impact on Anderson, who was then a freshman and preparing for his own standout high school career.

"I think it shows even now in C.J.," his former high school teammate, Patrick Little, said in a telephone conversation with USA TODAY Sports.

USA TODAY

49 memorable moments, fun facts from every Super Bowl

Little is now offensive coordinator at Bethel.

"It made him realize that you must take every moment as if it is your last," added Little. "That's why his intensity and drive are so strong. He has seen someone have everything one day and then suddenly they are gone."

Anderson rushed for 720 yards and five TDs in 15 games during the regular season, and his ability to generate yardage on the ground will likely be critical for the Broncos against the Carolina Panthers' stingy defense. The 24-year-old, who played his college ball at Cal, said that playing a Super Bowl so close to home is the "icing on the cake."

Vallejo is a blue-collar city that has endured serious difficulty. Property prices are roughly a quarter of those in San Francisco, just 28 miles away. The mid-1990s closure of a major shipyard resulted in thousands of job losses, and Vallejo declared bankruptcy in 2008.

With an overstretched school system, high crime rate and severe cuts in policing services, Vallejo's reputation has dipped compared to more affluent Bay Area neighborhoods. For Anderson, however, it is home -- and very much where the heart is.

USA TODAY

'Bittersweet' Super Bowl experience continues for Broncos LT Ryan Clady

"Before and after games, I think about where I came from and the people there," he said. "It is the easiest thing in the world to forget where you came from, but that is not an option for me. It made me who I am.

"It is an area that has had some difficult times, but it brings everyone close together. I know that they're behind me in whatever I do. ... I represent them every time I'm on the field."

Anderson's career was a struggle in itself. He spent two years at junior college to boost his academics before joining the Bears, where he wore jersey No. 9 in Pennerman's honor.

Despite going undrafted, he has become one of the cornerstones of the Broncos offense, with the run game more vital than ever due to Peyton Manning's waning powers.

USA TODAY

Wade Phillips: 'Quit Twittering me' for spot on Broncos

Jeff Turner, who has coached at Bethel for 17 years, says Anderson's links to his old school are far more than just lip service.

"C.J. comes back in the summertime to talk to the kids or to work out," Turner said. "You can tell he still feels this strong connection and feels that it is a part of him and his journey.

"He is a great figure of inspiration for us to use when we talk to the kids. He is a guy who didn't have it the easiest, but he fought through.

"And look at him now."

results.title: 'Bittersweet' Super Bowl experience continues for Broncos LT Ryan Clady
results.body:
USA TODAY Sports' Tom Pelissero gives his take on the insanity that is Super Bowl Media Day. USA TODAY Sports

91 CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

SANTA CLARA, Calif. -- Bittersweet describes Ryan Clady's Super Bowl experience.

For the second time in three years, his Denver Broncos are in the Super Bowl. And for the second time, the perennial Pro Bowl left tackle is missing the game with a season-ending injury.

Clady, the Broncos' longest tenured player, suffered a torn anterior cruciate ligament during a practice in May. In 2013, he spent most of the season on injured reserve after suffering a Lisfranc fracture.

"It's definitely bittersweet. I've played in this league eight years now, and the two times we go to the Super Bowl, I'm not out there," Clady told USA TODAY Sports. "I'm happy for my teammates, and I'm happy to be here this week. And I'm happy New England's not here, to be honest with you."

USA TODAY

Peyton Manning found comeback aide in Jordan Taylor

Clady's injury forced major changes to the offensive line and also put his future with the team in doubt. He is set to make $9.5 million in 2016 and $10 million in 2017 -- figures that might be too high for a guy with his recent injury history and a team that has many pressing contract issues to deal with.

"I would restructure," Clady said. "I would like to (stay). I've had a lot of teammates that left, so I've heard about what it's like around the league. I would like to stay here. I'm comfortable here. I like the city, and the fans are awesome."

The Broncos drafted a left tackle, Ty Sambrailo, in the second round last spring. But he, too, spent most of the year on injured reserve after suffering a shoulder injury in September.

The Broncos wound up playing most of the season with journeyman Ryan Harris at left tackle and second-year player Michael Schofield on the right side. Over the course of 18 games, Denver played four different line combinations with center Matt Paradis the only lineman to start every game.

USA TODAY

Broncos GM John Elway's Super Bowl advice to Peyton Manning: 'Stay in the moment'

And the turmoil often showed.

Peyton Manning was sacked 16 times in his first nine starts. Backup Brock Osweiler took 23 sacks in his seven starts, including five by Khalil Mack in the second half of a loss to the Oakland Raiders in December. Though Osweiler is more mobile and better able to escape the pocket than Manning, his tendency to hold the ball longer led to several sacks.

It's hard not to wonder then what the Broncos might have looked like with Clady and Sambrailo in the lineup. Yet it's difficult to picture because they barely even practiced together. But both stayed involved by going through their rehab processes in Denver, and they were both frequent visitors in the offensive line meetings. They've been at most home games and are here for Super Bowl week.

USA TODAY

Super Bowl 50 preview: How Panthers, Broncos stack up

Clady was among the injured players left behind during the week leading up to the Super Bowl in New Jersey two years ago.

"That's one of my best friends. To have him out here, to have this experience, to share it with one of my best friends has been awesome," Harris told USA TODAY Sports. "No one who knows him wanted him to go through what he's been through. But also, injuries are a part of the game.

"He's doing a great job. He's got his knee rehabbed, and he'll be continuing to play in the NFL."

***

Follow Lindsay H. Jones on Twitter @bylindsayhjones
