results.title: Panthers' Offense Face Tough Test on Sunday
results.body:
The Carolina Panthers' offense has been one of the best in the league this year but they will be going up against one of the best defenses in the league, the Denver Broncos.

The Carolina Panthers finished the year as the highest scoring offense, averaging 31.3 points per game. The postseason hasn't slowed this group down as the Panthers have score 31 points against the Seattle Seahawks and 49 points against the Arizona Cardinals. They have scored over 30 points in eight of the last nine games.

The Panthers' opponent in Super Bowl 50, the Denver Broncos, has one of the best defenses in the league this year. They rank near the top, if not the best, in a number of statistical categories.

Category Total Per Game Rank Total Yards 283.1 1st Passing Yards 199.6 1st Rushing Yards 83.6 3rd Points 18.5 4th Sacks 3.25 1st Takeaways 1.68 7th

The Broncos defense has done an excellent job of keeping teams off the scoreboard, holding opponents under 21 points in six out of the last seven games.

The biggest concern for the Panthers' has to be the pass rush of the Broncos with players like DeMarcus Ware, Von Miller and Shane Ray who have combined for 22.5 sacks in the regular season, which is more than the Buffalo Bills and Atlanta Falcons had all season.

While, the Broncos have an excellent defense the Panthers' defense pose a number of problems ranging from the speed of Ted Ginn Jr. and Philly Brown, the receiving threat of Greg Olsen from the tight end position to the run game led by Jonathan Stewart.

However, it is quarterback Cam Newton that is the biggest challenge and the Broncos' defensive coordinator Wade Phillips had high praise for him during Opening Night, according to this tweet from ESPN's Ed Werder.

https://twitter.com/Edwerderespn/status/694340886927245312

Newton isn't a stranger to some of the best defenses though. The Seahawks finished the regular season first in points against and the Cardinals finished seventh and the Panthers scored 80 points against them. He averaged 248 passing yards and scored a total of five touchdowns to only one interceptions in the two postseason games.

The Super Bowl is meant to be the game pitting the best the league has to offer and it is clear that this is one matchup that will do just that.

Twitter @BrandonCroce.

Follow us on Twitter @PanthersonScout and like our page on Facebook.

results.title: An Estimated $4.2 Billion is Expected to be Wagered on Super Bowl 50
results.body:
Every year, millions of people throughout America become football fans for a day, as they place their hard-earned money on some Super Bowl bets. Some money will be gambled on the outcome of the game itself, and some will be on wacky props for the coin flip, national anthem, or halftime show. Some will be legally wagered, and plenty more will be illegally wagered.

Total it all up, and the American Gaming Association is predicting that Americans will wager a total of at least $4.2-billion on Super Bowl 50 between the Denver Broncos and the Carolina Panthers.

According to the Nevada Gaming Control Board, only $116-million was wagered legally on last year's big game between the Patriots and Seahawks-$3.4 million less than the amount of money legally placed on Super Bowl XLVIII between the Broncos and Seahawks. Take those numbers into consideration and it appears as though nearly 97% of the $4.2-billion placed on Sunday's game will be illegally wagered.

At the moment, the Panthers are 5.5-point favorites to beat the Broncos, and the Broncos are paying 2-to-1 to win the game straight-up. The over-under is set at 45 points.

Contact your local bookie to get your plays in before game time.

results.title: Youth and Experience to Clash in Historic Super Bowl 50
results.body:
Super Bowl 50 takes place this coming Sunday, and it will feature a young, up-and-coming Carolina team with MVP hopeful quarterback Cam Newton going up against the Denver Broncos and the 39-year-old future Hall of Famer Peyton Manning, who will likely be playing in the final game of his career and hoping to go out on top with a Lombardi trophy just like his boss, John Elway.

The Carolina Panthers went 15-1 this season, anchored by the best defense in the league with all-pro defenders Luke Kuechly at linebacker and Josh Norman at cornerback. Newton took the next step in his development this season and asserted himself as an elite quarterback, even with few weapons outside of tight end Greg Olsen. Newton threw for 35 touchdowns and ran for another 10. The Panthers offense is well-balanced and lethal; they rolled over the Arizona Cardinals' stout defense by a score of 49-14 in the NFC Championship game. They come into Super Bowl 50 with a chip on their shoulder, as many predicted that the team would fail to even make the playoffs let alone be the best team in the NFL.

The Denver Broncos went 12-4 and were the AFC's No. 1 seed, yet this was mainly due to their second-ranked defense in the league, and not the play of Manning, who threw 17 interceptions (second in the league) and only nine touchdowns in the worst statistical season of his career that resulted in him backing up Brock Osweiler when he returned from injury. Although he played just well enough to take down the defending champion New England Patriots in the AFC Championship, he was a little more than a game manager. Against a team as well-rounded as Carolina, they are going to need Manning to step up and deliver one more time.

The Super Bowl has essentially become an unofficial holiday in America. In turn, many students on campus here at Ramapo are excited for the game. Nothing demonstrates this better than the fact that there is a six-hour pre-game show. It has become an event that transcends sports and is now ingrained in American culture, and everyone from the hardcore football fan to the casual observer is looking forward to the game.

Freshman Aslan Peret is looking forward to the game, and although he will be rooting for the Broncos, he's not very optimistic.

"As much as I'd love to see Peyton win another Super Bowl, I think the Panthers are the better team," said Peret. "No matter what happens, this is going to be a game people will remember for a long time."

Sophomore Ryan Bush is a huge football fan and could not be looking forward more to this game. "You've got the legend in Peyton Manning going up against an up-and-coming superstar in Cam Newton," said Bush. "This could be Peyton's last game and possibly Newton's first of many Super Bowl appearances; what's not to like?"

In Super Bowl 50, we have the two best defenses in the league going up against radically different offenses run by quarterbacks with two different styles of play, who represent different eras.

Manning is a pro-style "3-step drop back and pass" quarterback, which NFL offenses have been built around for the last 50 years. Newton is a dual-threat quarterback, one that is mobile and can beat you on the ground but also has an outstanding arm. Manning, possibly the greatest quarterback to ever play the game, is playing in what is likely his final game, and Newton, who this season joined Manning as an elite quarterback, is playing in his first Super Bowl at the age of 26.

In many ways, this game is a passing of the torch between an established, future Hall of Fame quarterback to one that has all the talent to eventually be one as well. Both defenses are outstanding, meaning this game is likely to come down to which quarterback is going to be able to better lead their offense and make the critical plays in the second half of the game.

results.title: Teams address media ahead of Super Bowl 50
results.body:
The Super Bowl teams addressed the media Monday night for the first time since arriving in California.

Eyewitness News sports anchor Phil Orban and reporter Lawrence Gilligan got a first-hand look at the questions the Carolina Panthers and the Denver Broncos are facing.

Media day is dubbed Super Bowl 50 opening night at the SAP Center, home of the San Jose Sharks.

More than 5,500 media members have credentials for the event where the Broncos took the stage first followed by the Panthers.

Watch Eyewitness News at 10 and 11 pm for full coverage.

results.title: Super Bowl Opening Night 2016: Best Moments and Twitter Reaction from Media Day
results.body:
Puppets, dancing leprechauns and hundreds of reporters searching for soundbites. Welcome to the Super Bowl opening night.

Monday's event in the SAP Center in San Jose was the inaugural Super Bowl opening night, a prime-time version of the traditional Tuesday media day. It was also the first time the two teams officially addressed the media since arriving in the San Francisco area.

Fans were allowed to attend, and Michael David Smith of Pro Football Talk said thousands bought tickets at $27.50 each.

Football almost always takes a backseat during media day at the Super Bowl, and Monday's opening night was no different. Tom Pelissero of USA Today realized more than just human journalists were at the event:

Two puppets doing a press conference in Spanish. I have no idea what is happening. pic.twitter.com/YeibSDARsO -- Tom Pelissero (@TomPelissero)

February 2, 2016

Kyle Meinke of MLive.com shared an interesting image:

The Super Bowl is for serious journalists only pic.twitter.com/gciBHgzsw9 -- Kyle Meinke (@kmeinke)

February 2, 2016

Melissa Jacobs of Sports Illustrated caught another character:

Not many oddly dressed folks tonight. Here's an exception... pic.twitter.com/Ni2xa1RuiO -- Melissa Jacobs (@thefootballgirl)

February 2, 2016

It wasn't just superheroes, puppets and even the occasional football journalist in attendance. Joe Fann of 49ers.com noticed Miss Universe was in San Jose for the event:

Miss Universe in the house. (Insert Steve Harvey joke here) #SB50 #SBMediaDay pic.twitter.com/ZFBS5KgphO -- Joe Fann (@Joe_Fann)

February 2, 2016

Denver also had an unofficial mascot looking for attention, per Bleacher Report NFL:

Things are getting weird at #SB50 Opening Night... pic.twitter.com/92cVCPJmLM -- Bleacher Report NFL (@BR_NFL)

February 2, 2016

The Broncos were first on the stage for interviews, and defensive coordinator Wade Phillips was dressed for success. Phil Milani of DenverBroncos.com captured an image, and Phillips responded accordingly:

@philmilani drippin -- Wade Phillips (@sonofbum)

February 2, 2016

John Breech of CBS Sports passed along an image of the Broncos taking the stage:

Peyton Manning already has his game face on. #Broncos pic.twitter.com/WU5pXIt3tN -- John Breech (@johnbreech)

February 2, 2016

More than a few reporters were there to see Peyton Manning, per Darren Rovell of ESPN.com:

Only a few members of the media here to see Peyton Manning #whatcaucus pic.twitter.com/pHgmZ7KnyQ -- Darren Rovell (@darrenrovell)

February 2, 2016

Manning did manage to offer at least one meaningful answer in the scrum, per the NFL:

"Is this your last game?"

Peyton Manning responds to @MarshallFaulk. #SBOpeningNight #SB50 https://t.co/wYMpAlMkYR -- NFL (@NFL)

February 2, 2016

Manning jokingly said the Panthers may have to use a spy against him in the Super Bowl after he notched a 12-yard run against the New England Patriots in the AFC Championship Game, per Ben Baskin of Sports Illustrated. The signal-caller also said he believes his counterpart, Cam Newton, is on his way to individual recognition, per NFL on ESPN: "No doubt in my mind he'll be the MVP."

The Broncos quarterback also addressed the NFL's investigation into his link with HGH, per Troy Renck of the Denver Post: "I know what they will find, a big fat nothing. I know rules and respect rules."

Manning's receivers also took the podium, and it is safe to say Demaryius Thomas won't be sticking around to watch the halftime show Sunday, per Jane McManus of ESPN.com:

"Demaryius what's your favorite Coldplay song?"

"Who?"

"Coldplay? Have a favorite song?"

"No." pic.twitter.com/LzSCsS7gCN -- Jane McManus (@janesports)

February 2, 2016

Manning's other top receiver, Emmanuel Sanders, weighed in on the matchup, per NFL Network:

Underdog or favorite, doesn't matter. @ESanders_10 just wants to lift that trophy. #FanOpeningNight pic.twitter.com/FIgtvWIOEp -- NFL Network (@nflnetwork)

February 2, 2016

On the defensive side, cornerback Aqib Talib responded to rumors that Calvin Johnson may retire, per ESPN's Adam Schefter, by saying the Detroit Lions wide receiver "is the toughest cover in the league," per Meinke. Talib also fielded a question about the local surroundings and said he would "holla at one of the female guards for a couple years, have her get a little key or something and walk right out the building" to escape Alcatraz, per Jeff Howe of the Boston Herald.

However, Talib turned heads for more reasons than his Johnson and Alcatraz analysis, as Mike Sando of ESPN.com shared:

Aqib Talib's Rolex watch, which he called an "$80,000 Rolley" https://t.co/r0n5xzoo79 pic.twitter.com/oCWKm7o4Xw -- Mike Sando, ESPN.com (@SandoESPN)

February 2, 2016

Talib wasn't the only one with flashy jewelry in the Broncos secondary, per Sando:

TJ Ward reveals that he and Aqib Talib use the same jeweler ("Gabe") and that his "Jesus... https://t.co/bo3nqKol6P pic.twitter.com/FcZTljEUR9 -- Mike Sando, ESPN.com (@SandoESPN)

February 2, 2016

As the Panthers began their session, Rovell explained why it was so crowded:

Press credentialed for Super Bowl I: 338

Press credentialed for Super Bowl 50: 5,000+ -- Darren Rovell (@darrenrovell)

February 2, 2016

Including people like this inflates those totals, per Nicki Jhabvala of the Denver Post:

This is when it gets awkward. #SB50 pic.twitter.com/6W8h14uUPn -- Nicki Jhabvala (@NickiJhabvala)

February 2, 2016

Bette Marston of Sports Illustrated passed along an image of the Panthers taking the stage:

Who's ready for round two? Here are the Carolina Panthers! pic.twitter.com/dWNBajA14W -- Bette Marston (@bettemarston)

February 2, 2016

Cornerback Josh Norman captured attention with his outfit, as Julie Stewart-Binks of Fox Sports shared:

Josh Norman having a good time with media day. pic.twitter.com/i9hx5AyQNS -- Julie Stewart-Binks (@JSB_FOX)

February 2, 2016

Norman's fellow defender Luke Kuechly revealed he's afraid of heights, per Mindi Bach of CSN Bay Area, but it was Newton who almost tumbled from his 6'5" height, as Bleacher Report NFL captured:

Cam almost took a mean Lhttps://t.co/cJnyiVHZNp -- Bleacher Report NFL (@BR_NFL)

February 2, 2016

Newton also made headlines with his pants as the Panthers arrived in California, and he responded to wardrobe questions, per Sports Illustrated, "The black-and-gold attire that I had in my closet was extremely limited." SB Nation NFL provided another glimpse at the pants:

Cam Newton wore these pants because of Super Bowl 50. "My black & gold wardrobe is limited"https://t.co/tGSS9a47Sy pic.twitter.com/FMI1oIn0nZ -- SB Nation NFL (@SBNationNFL)

February 2, 2016

Newton made sure to let Panthers fans know they have plenty to look forward to, per Around the NFL: "I plan to do a lot more dancing in my career, and I plan to do some more dancing Sunday if I have reason to dance."

In between the fashion discussion was meaningful insight from linebacker Thomas Davis, who broke his forearm in the NFC Championship Game, per Jonathan Jones of the Charlotte Observer: "Without a doubt I will be playing Super Bowl Sunday."

The Panthers are a strong defense with Davis on the field, but Denver also boasts a formidable group. Kuechly addressed the opposition, per the NFL:

What does @LukeKuechly think of the @Broncos' defense?

He likes what he sees. #SBOpeningNight #SB50 https://t.co/yVJWex5A74 -- NFL (@NFL)

February 2, 2016

While there were serious answers from some Panthers, there were also some interesting interviewers, as Bryan Strickland of Panthers.com shared:

I have no answers. pic.twitter.com/o5KrnLodpi -- Bryan Strickland (@PanthersBryan)

February 2, 2016

Joe Person of the Charlotte Observer found another:

Miss Universe interviews @bbersin10 and Andrew Norwell. pic.twitter.com/lJ7NkaVYdG -- Joe Person (@josephperson)

February 2, 2016

A young reporter stole the show, though, per the NFL:

Kid reporter: "When I'm in the end zone, I do the dab just like you!"

Cam: "No you don't. What!?" #SBOpeningNight https://t.co/wAJunZs0O4 -- NFL (@NFL)

February 2, 2016

Newton seemed to enjoy his interaction with the younger interviewer, but he left some thinking after this response to a question about his place in the sports hierarchy, per Lindsey Adler of BuzzFeed News:

Reporter: Are you the LeBron of the NFL?

Cam: "Why can't LeBron be the Cam Newton of power forwards?" -- Lindsey Adler (@Lahlahlindsey)

February 2, 2016

Despite the circus atmosphere Monday, the teams will now become more serious as they turn their attention toward the game. Newton said, "We believe in ourselves, we believe in our coaching and in our preparation," per NFL on ESPN.

With Newton's talent leading the way, that may be all it takes to win the Lombardi Trophy.

What's Next?

Now that the antics and interviews of Super Bowl opening night are in the rearview mirror, it is time for the football world to turn its attention toward the game.

There are plenty of storylines to follow, including the battle between one of the all-time greats in Manning and the likely MVP of the league in Newton. Manning is no longer the dominant force he once was, but all it would take is one throwback performance Sunday to lift the Lombardi Trophy. As for Newton, if he plays like he did all season, with 45 total touchdowns, Carolina will likely win the title.

Perhaps the most important matchup is the one between the Panthers offense and the stifling Denver Broncos defense.

Carolina scored a combined 80 points in its two postseason victories against the Arizona Cardinals and Seattle Seahawks, but Denver was first in the league in total defense and fourth in scoring defense this season. The Broncos stopped Tom Brady in the AFC Championship Game, but containing the dual-threat Newton will prove to be even more difficult with the Super Bowl hanging in the balance.

Monday may have been a relaxing evening for the Denver defenders, but watching tape of Newton in preparation for Sunday's contest won't be.

results.title: Peyton still mum on retirement, backs Cam for MVP
results.body:
56 CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Peyton Manning had no interest in making any announcement Monday about his future plans to a throng of media on Super Bowl Opening Night.

The Denver Broncos quarterback once again stiff-armed questions about whether he plans to retire after Super Bowl 50.

"I don't know the answer to that," Manning said when asked about whether he would be playing his final game.

NFL Films cameras captured Manning telling Bill Belichick after the AFC Championship Game "this might be my last rodeo." The quarterback acknowledged his comments while still giving himself some wiggle room.

"What I said was true: This could be it. ... Doesn't mean it will be it," Manning said.

Manning added that he was just trying to take in the moment as he entered his fourth Super Bowl in pursuit of his second title.

"Seeing other people enjoying the moment reminds me I need to be enjoying this as well," Manning said.

The five-time MVP also backed Super Bowl opponent and Carolina Panthers quarterback Cam Newton for this year's award.

"He's just had this incredible year," Manning said. "No doubt in my mind he'll win the MVP. He's been awesome - that's the best word I can think of."

Manning also held firm on his stance regarding an Al Jazeera America report alleging HGH shipments were delivered to his house in his wife's name, an accusation the NFL is currently investigating. He called the report "a complete farce, a fabrication."

"Like I said in December, I welcome it," Manning said of the investigation. "I respect the rules of the game. They're very important to me. And I welcome it, because I know what they're going to find: a big, fat no."

PHOTOS: Best of Super Bowl Media Night

results.title: Live updates from Super Bowl 50 Opening Night
results.body:
100 CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Super Bowl 50 week officially kicks off as the Denver Broncos and Carolina Panthers meet with the media for the first time. The NFL turned it's normal media day into a prime time event: "Super Bowl 50 Opening Night." The event at the SAP Center in San Jose, Calif. is airing on NFL Network at 8 p.m. ET.

Here are some of the highlights from Super Bowl 50 Opening Night:

Quite possibly the best moment from tonight

Austin Denton a 14-year-old cancer survivor interviewd Peyton Manning.

A look from aboveExcuse me, what?

"It's the 50th Super Bowl, so I thought I'd bring our favorite sport to the States,'' Phillip Hajszan told USA TODAY Sports. "It's about bringing Austria to the Super Bowl.''

Turns out Austrians are growing increasingly fond of American football, according to Hajszan, who noted that while Peyton Manning makes for a splendid quarterback, he might be natural on the ski slopes.

"From the way he's walking, just from the look,'' Hajszan said, "he has the right legs to ski well.''

USA TODAY

Sportscasters' outrageous outfits ramp up media day wackiness

...and he doesn't want to answer retirement questions

Denver Broncos quarterback Peyton Manning had no interest in making any announcement Monday about his future plans to a throng of media on Super Bowl Opening Night. #sb50 #sbopeningnight #peytonmanning #broncos #broncoscountryplayoffs

results.title: Meet wacky characters of SB50 media day
results.body:
40 CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

SAN JOSE -- It was the annual Super Bowl media day, so of course the crowd included a downhill Austrian skier with a mini video camera mounted atop his crash helmet.

OK, so it was actually an Austrian sportscaster, clad in an attention-getting outfit, who helped put the me into media day.

"It's the 50th Super Bowl, so I thought I'd bring our favorite sport to the States,'' Phillip Hajszan told USA TODAY Sports. "It's about bringing Austria to the Super Bowl.''

Hajszan is no newcomer to the Super Bowl media day, but the shtick is. During six previous appearances, he's brought an Austrian flavor and costume while dressed up as Mozart, The Terminator (a.k.a. Arnold Schwarzenegger) and a yodeler in lederhosen.

Turns out Austrians are growing increasingly fond of American football, according to Hajszan, who noted that while Peyton Manning makes for a splendid quarterback, he might be natural on the ski slopes.

"From the way he's walking, just from the look,'' Hajszan said, "he has the right legs to ski well.''

-----

Elsewhere in the throng was Denver sportscaster Arran Anderson. Viewers had implored him to burn the orange, blue and white argyle-patterned sports jacket he wore in honor of the Denver Broncos during Super Bowl XLVIII -- where the team got clobbered by the Seattle Seahawks 43-8.

So when Anderson showed up at Super Bowl media day Monday in an orange, blue and white argyle-patterned coat, he wanted to clarify something for Broncos' fans and viewers of KMZH-TV in Denver.

"Hey, this is a whole new jacket,'' Andersen told USA TODAY Sports. "This has no negativity tied to what happened in Super Bowl XLVIII. We're talking about a clean slate.''

Both jackets were ordered through Loudmouth, the same company that supplies John Daly with head-turning golf outfits.

Of his Broncos-colored blazer, Andersen said, "I think it's visible from outer space to be honest with you.''

------

On Super Bowl media day, there was runaway winner for oddest business card: "Rocky The Colorado Leprechaun.''

Not only did the famed Denver Broncos fan show up in his garish orange and blue regalia, but he also had a fistful of business cards.

"I've been Rocky The Leprechaun,'' said the man who identifies himself as only, you guessed it, Rocky The Leprechaun.

But his own website -- www.RockyTheLeprechaun.com -- blows his cover. His real name is Rocky Brougham, and his the leprechaun shtick started as St. Patrick's Day entertainment in 1976. Broughan says he's been to every Broncos home game since 1982 and attended each of their five Super Bowls.

For Rocky, Broncos football is serious business -- and he has the cards to prove it.

-----

On an arena floor full of media badges -- and accompanying media members -- Hal Bonilla of the California Highway Patrol proudly wore around his a badge that distinguished him from all others.

It was a commemorative badge, featuring at the center an image of the Lombardi trophy, awarded to the Super Bowl champions. The badges are available to law enforcement members in northern California for $145, according to Sgt. Bonilla.

But his T-shirt was priceless. The design was split in half, Carolina Panthers on one side and Denver Broncos on the other side.

"Pretty much a household divided,'' he said, explaining that his wife is from Denver and he likes the Carolina Panthers. "May the best team win.''

PHOTOS: Best of Super Bowl Opening Night

results.title: NFL Network reporter has spectacular on-air flub
results.body:
Per SB Nation, while introducing Aloe Blacc for the opening Super Bowl 50 Media Day performance, NFL Network reporter Melissa Stark had an unfortunate slip of the tongue.

These things happen, you know? It's not totally dissimilar to trying to run before you've actually caught the pass.

Here's to hoping the rest of the broadcast goes off without a hitch. As if that's even a remotely possible thing.

results.title: Broncos 2016: Twitter Reactions to Super Bowl Media Day
results.body:
The Denver Broncos have arrived in California and had their big media session on Monday. Here are some of the answers and reactions from the day.

It is finally here Broncos Country. We are in Super Bowl Week. Only six more days until the biggest game of the year and our Broncos team is in it!

The team began preparations in California after arriving Sunday from Denver. Today, they held practice at Stanford University before meeting with the media at the SAP Center in San Jose.

Normally, media day would take place on the Tuesday before the big game. However, with this being Super Bowl 50, there was no doubt there would be a bigger stage for this one.

This media session can feature any and all questions that writers, reporters, bloggers, and such can think about. There is no knowing what kind of questions will be asked.

One question that I know in particular is Peyton Manning being asked how family dinners go in the Manning household while being handed a playbook.

With the various amount of questions, I have taken to Twitter and posted some of the best reactions and even some of the questions that were asked by the various media members.

Brandon Marshall: "We were embarrassed, [in SB 48] we're definitely looking forward to a better outcome." pic.twitter.com/t51cPx6iAZ

-- Broncos SPORTalk (@SPORTalkBroncos) February 2, 2016

Shane Ray's rap battle. If you ask players to rap battle at media day, they will do it, apparently. pic.twitter.com/0za83tmiXu

-- Troy Machir (@TroyMachir) February 2, 2016

Broncos DC Wade Phillips says that what separates his 2015 defense from other great ones he's coached is how they perform under pressure.

-- Albert Breer (@AlbertBreer) February 2, 2016

Keep it here at Predominantly Orange as we continue to provide you with coverage leading up to Super Bowl 50! Go Broncos!

results.title: Broncos DC: 'Quit Twittering me' to join team
results.body:
CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

SAN JOSE - Denver Broncos defensive coordinator Wade Phillips didn't expect to get such a significant contribution from safety Shiloh Keo, who signed with the team soon after sending a tweet to Phillips in December asking to keep him in mind.

"No. In fact, if people would quit Twittering me now to try to get on the team, I would appreciate it," Phillips said with a smile during Monday night's Super Bowl 50 media event. "I've had tons of people saying, 'Hey, I played in junior high and I know I can help you."

USA TODAY

How one Broncos player used Twitter to revive NFL dream

Keo, 28, had a prior connection with Phillips, who coached him with the Houston Texans from 2011 to '13. The Texans cut Keo in October 2014, and he was out of the league until the Broncos - short-handed in the secondary because of injuries - signed him Dec. 9.

No other compelling prospects among all those tweets?

"No," Phillips said. "I haven't come up with any yet that even played football."

Follow Tom Pelissero on Twitter @TomPelissero.

results.title: Kartje: Broncos transform from offensive powerhouse to defensive juggernaut
results.body:
When the Denver Broncos last graced the Super Bowl stage just two years ago, they arrived in East Rutherford, N.J., with one of the most prolific offenses the NFL had ever seen.

In 13 of their 18 games before the Super Bowl, the 2013 Broncos put up at least 30 points. No team in the history of the league scored more over the course of a single season (606). No quarterback had ever thrown for as many yards (5,477) or touchdowns (55) as Peyton Manning, who was putting together the best campaign of his Hall of Fame career. Manning's dominance had been so complete that five of Denver's skill position players surpassed the 10-touchdown mark - yet another single-season record. And they showed no signs of slowing down. Two weeks earlier, in an AFC title game, Manning and his supporting cast picked the New England Patriots apart, to the tune of 400 yards and two touchdowns.

By most measures, the Broncos offense appeared unstoppable.

That is, until the opening snap of the Super Bowl soared over Manning's head, and suddenly, at the worst possible time, it wasn't.

In fact, the Seattle Seahawks and their equally prolific "Legion of Boom" defense so thoroughly dominated the Broncos in an embarrassing, 43-8 Super Bowl blowout that day that John Elway, a Denver legend and the team's general manager, didn't just tinker with the direction of the franchise in the weeks to follow. He pulled a complete, fundamental 180.

After an historically high-scoring season, the Hall of Fame quarterback and architect of the NFL's best offense in decades decided, instead, to build around his defense.

Two years later, one of the league's most impressive roster transformations ever is complete. The Broncos are back on the NFL's biggest stage this week, with barely any resemblance to the explosive, offensive team that fell apart in 2014. Only six starters from Super Bowl XLVIII will start in the same role Sunday against the Carolina Panthers, with Manning - coming off the worst and most likely last season of his NFL career - being one. Twenty-four months removed from trotting out an elite offense in New Jersey, the Broncos will take the field in Santa Clara with the second-lowest scoring offense to ever reach the league's biggest game.

But its defense, thanks to Elway's vision and aggressive moves in free agency, might be just as good as the Seattle unit Elway set out to emulate after Denver's Super Bowl embarrassment. This year's Broncos defense led the NFL in total yards allowed (283.1 per game), pass yards allowed (199.6 per game), yards per play allowed (4.4), fewest plays of 20 yards or more (46), and sacks (52). At every level, the Broncos defense is designed to wreak havoc on opposing quarterbacks, and in 2015, it did just that, better than anyone, by a significant margin.

Many of the building blocks of that terrorizing defense were already in place when Elway set out to revamp his defense after the 2013 season, but only one starter, safety David Bruton, was inherited when he took the job in 2011. Von Miller, who has graded as a top-three edge rusher by Pro Football Focus in each of his five NFL seasons, was Elway's first draft pick as an executive that April. A few months later, before training camp, he signed undrafted free-agent cornerback Chris Harris Jr., who in a matter of three seasons, has become an All-Pro. In the 2012 draft, Elway added Derek Wolfe and Malik Jackson, both of whom have been crucial up front this season.

But it was Elway's riskier moves that have paid the biggest dividends in Denver's defensive transformation. While conventional knowledge suggests that teams are better off building through the draft, Elway wasted no time raiding the 2014 free agent market for difference-makers on defense. In a single day, Elway shelled out $110 million in contracts to three defensive free agents - edge rusher DeMarcus Ware, cornerback Aqib Talib, and safety T.J. Ward. All three have been among the NFL's best at their positions since.

Elway's final master touch, however, came this offseason, when he hired an out-of-work Wade Phillips to helm the Denver defense. Phillips, with his typically dominant 3-4 defense installed, proceeded to create a monster.

On Jan. 24, in the Broncos' AFC championship victory over the Patriots, the defense that Elway had so aggressively built put together its piece de resistance. With its offense sputtering, the Broncos defense knocked down Patriots quarterback Tom Brady 18 times, despite blitzing on only 17.2 percent of New England's snaps - a season-low for the rush-happy Phillips. With few blitzes, the Broncos defense stifled the future Hall of Famer with an extra man in the secondary, while Denver's four-man rush of Miller, Ware, Wolfe and Jackson created pressure 48.7 percent of the time, according to Pro Football Focus.

To beat the Panthers and soon-to-be league MVP Cam Newton, it'll take a similar Herculean effort. Unless Manning shows flashes of his 2013 self on Sunday's ride into the sunset, the Broncos will have no shot at outgunning the Panthers in a Super Bowl shootout. Denver's offense has scored 30 points just twice this season - and only once in regulation. Carolina's offense surpassed the 30-point mark eight times during the regular season and in each of its two playoff games.

Stopping Newton is a far different task than stopping a pocket-bound Brady. While Brady was knocked down 18 times by the Broncos, Newton has been sacked just 18 times all season.

While under pressure, though, Newton, like most any other quarterback, has been far less effective, with an equal ratio of touchdowns (six) to interceptions. And no defense in the NFL is as capable of forcing Newton outside the pocket as the Broncos. If Denver can make Carolina one-dimensional, anything is possible.

So before joining the masses on the Panthers' bandwagon this week - they're 51/2-point favorites, after all - consider this: Since 1970, teams with the NFL's top defense are 9-2 in the Super Bowl.

But are the Broncos, with a prolific defense and pedestrian offense, good enough to continue the trend?

Elway, two years and hundreds of millions into Denver's roster transformation, is betting on it.

results.title: Denver rallies Sunday to support Broncos in Super Bowl
results.body:
Denver Broncos long-snapper Aaron Brewer likes flying under the radar

The looming snow storm aimed at Denver didn't stop Broncos fans from giving their team a Super Bowl send-off Sunday afternoon.

An estimated 7,500 fans showed up at Denver's Civic Center for the Broncos Country Fan Rally, according to Scott Gilmore, the deputy manager of parks and recreation.

"With the snow coming we were worried, but they turned out really well," Gilmore said. "Wait until we bring home the trophy. There will be a million people out here."

PHOTOS: Fans celebrated the Denver Broncos heading to Super Bowl 50

As the event went into full swing, Broncos cheerleaders signed autographs, and former players made predictions about the outcome of next week's Super Bowl. The rally also featured an appearance from Miles the Mascot.

But celebrating with devoted fans from the Mile High City was the motivation for several fans who showed up for the rally.

"I'm feeling that Mile High energy," said Jason Phelan, a 30-year-old salesman from Denver. "I would just love to see them bring a trophy home. I think they deserve it, and we have a good chance."

Above the crowd chanting "Go, Broncos" Miguel Sifuentes, 37, waved a massive, homemade Broncos flag. He said the flag will travel with him to California this week when he cheers on the Broncos at the Super Bowl.

"We've got to do our thing in the stands, and they've got to do their thing on the field," he said.

Fans who aren't attending the game turned out at the rally to gear up for their own celebrations.

Tate Gilpin, a 28-year-old Denver resident, said he and his friends will unite in orange at their annual Super Bowl viewing party.

"The fans are going to have an impact," he said. "If you're not a true fan, don't be in the room with me during the game."

results.title: Broncos' Osweiler unconcerned about NFL future
results.body:
SAN JOSE, Calif. - Without a change in facial expression, Broncos backup quarterback Brock Osweiler said he has given no thought to the possibility of starter Peyton Manning possibility retiring, or the possible riches that could await in free agency this spring.

Really.

Those are bridges across distant rivers, Osweiler said numerous times during the NFL's "Opening Night" on Monday night.

"I haven't had time to," he said. "When we're not on the practice field, I'm watching tape, and when I'm not watching tape, I'm doing body work or something like that. When that bridge comes, we'll cross it at that time."

AZCENTRAL

Live updates: Super Bowl 50 Opening Night

Osweiler, a product of Arizona State, was asked how he could not let his mind wander to events beyond Sunday's Super Bowl against the Panthers.

"I can't control it," Osweiler said. "My college coordinator (Noel Mazzone) told me my sophomore year in college, 'Brock, only worry about the things you can control.'

"And I can't control whether Peyton keeps playing football or he doesn't. So I'm not going to think about it. I'm not going to worry about it. I'm going to show up and do my job to the best of my abilities every day, every week."

AZCENTRAL

Arizona Cardinals will be fine, CBS' NFL experts say

A second-round pick by the Broncos in 2012, Osweiler's first NFL start came this year when Manning suffered a foot injury. The Broncos went 5-2 in games Osweiler started, but coach Gary Kubiak went back to Manning for the playoffs.

"When that situation did take place, I went home and talked to my wife," Osweiler said. "My biggest thing during that couple weeks when that was going on, I just wanted to be the best teammate I could be.

"I think that's what makes this whole football team special. We all care about each other. As long as we're winning football games, I'm happy."

results.title: Live updates: Super Bowl 50 Opening Night
results.body:
Already a subscriber, but don't have a login?

Register your digital access.

Super Bowl 50 week officially kicks off as the Denver Broncos and Carolina Panthers meet with the media for the first time. The NFL turned it's normal media day into a prime time event: "Super Bowl 50 Opening Night." The event at the SAP Center in San Jose, Calif. is airing on NFL Network at 8 p.m. ET.

Here are some of the highlights from Super Bowl 50 Opening Night:

A look from aboveExcuse me, what?

"It's the 50th Super Bowl, so I thought I'd bring our favorite sport to the States,'' Phillip Hajszan told USA TODAY Sports. "It's about bringing Austria to the Super Bowl.''

Turns out Austrians are growing increasingly fond of American football, according to Hajszan, who noted that while Peyton Manning makes for a splendid quarterback, he might be natural on the ski slopes.

"From the way he's walking, just from the look,'' Hajszan said, "he has the right legs to ski well.''

USA TODAY

results.title: Von Miller: I want to win for DeMarcus, Peyton and Wade
results.body:
Broncos outside linebacker Von Miller wants to win the Super Bowl on Sunday for himself, of course, but there are also three people in the locker room in particular he'd like to help get a ring.

Miller said today that his fellow outside linebacker DeMarcus Ware, quarterback Peyton Manning and defensive coordinator Wade Phillips are the three people he's most motivated to win for.

"I want to do it for DeMarcus and Peyton and Coach Phillips," Miller said at Super Bowl Opening Night.

Ware has been in the NFL for 11 years, and this is his first Super Bowl. Manning is expected to retire after the season, and it would be fitting to see him ride off into the sunset with a Super Bowl title. Phillips has coached in the NFL for 40 years and doesn't have a ring.

Miller said there's a lot of camaraderie in the Broncos' locker room, and so players feel like they're playing for each other.

"It's like a college atmosphere in our locker room," Miller said. "We spend a lot of time together and I think that's the glue that makes things go."

results.title: Seahawks' pre-Super Bowl mock draft roundup
results.body:
The eyes of the football world are on San Francisco this week, as the Denver Broncos and Carolina Panthers prepare to meet in Super Bowl 50 on Sunday.

For Seahawks fans, it's still a bit of a shock not to be watching their team play in the world's biggest sporting event for the third straight season. So instead of focusing on Peyton Manning and Cam Newton, we'll look ahead to April's NFL draft.

For our third 2016 mock draft roundup, we went around the internet to see whom the experts pegged to come to Seattle this spring. Perhaps unsurprisingly, the picks fell into just three position groups.

results.title: Broncos GM John Elway's Super Bowl advice to Peyton Manning: 'Stay in the moment'
results.body:
USA TODAY Sports' Tom Pelissero discusses the week leading up to Super Bowl 50. USA TODAY Sports

102 CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

SAN JOSE -- John Elway, the only man who might truly understand how Peyton Manning feels heading into Super Bowl 50, a game that could be his last, doesn't want the Denver Broncos quarterback to spend any time worrying about his future right now.

"He's worked too hard to get to where he is now to talk about if he's going to end it now or not," Elway said Monday night. "He's going to have plenty of time in the offseason to reminisce and look back. His key thing is, concentrate, stay in the moment. This is what he worked for."

Elway, the Broncos' general manager, retired after winning his second Super Bowl title in January 1999 at age 38. But he seems reticent to offer his quarterback too much advice ahead of what could be Manning's final game.

USA TODAY

Peyton Manning remains mum on retirement, backs Cam for MVP

Manning, who will turn 40 in March, missed six and a half games with a foot injury and had the worst statistical seasons of his career, including 17 interceptions in nine regular-season starts.

For Elway, the retirement decision 17 years ago was mostly a matter of health. He missed time his final year with a hamstring injury, and he finally decided his body just couldn't hold up any longer.

Of course, winning his second consecutive title helped.

Manning cwould match Elway's ring total with a win Sunday against the Carolina Panthers.

USA TODAY

Sportscasters' outrageous outfits ramp up media day wackiness

"The bottom line is that you have to stay in the moment. The one thing you don't want to do is think about not playing while you are still playing," Elway said.

"At some point, you're not going to be able to play. So it's important to stay in the moment, enjoy what he is going through right now, the hard work that he's put in this year to get himself where he is now, hopefully win this last game. And then in the offseason he can sit down and figure out what he wants to do."

Contributing: Eric Prisbell

***

Follow Lindsay H. Jones on Twitter @bylindsayhjones

results.title: Peyton mum on retirement, backs Cam for MVP
results.body:
CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Peyton Manning had no interest in making any announcement Monday about his future plans to a throng of media on Super Bowl Opening Night.

The Denver Broncos quarterback once again stiff-armed questions about whether he plans to retire after Super Bowl 50.

"I don't know the answer to that," Manning said when asked about whether he would be playing his final game.

Manning added that he was just trying to take in the moment as he entered his fourth Super Bowl in pursuit of his second title.

"Seeing other people enjoying the moment reminds me I need to be enjoying this as well," Manning said.

The five-time MVP also backed Super Bowl opponent and Carolina Panthers quarterback Cam Newton for this year's award.

"He's just had this incredible year," Manning said. "No doubt in my mind he'll win the MVP. He's been awesome - that's the best word I can think of."

PHOTOS: Best of Super Bowl Media Night

results.title: Broncos sing Cam Newton praises during Super Bowl Opening Night
results.body:
The Broncos are well aware of the challenges Panthers quarterback Cam Newton presents.

Denver defenders praised Newton on Monday during Super Bowl 50 Opening Night at the SAP Center in San Jose.

"He's the best player they have. He might be the best player in the league," Broncos linebacker Von Miller said of Newton. "Cam is a super tough player to take down, he controls that whole offense. As Cam goes, that offense goes."

PHOTOS: Best of Super Bowl Opening Night | Newton's dances

Newton will likely be the NFL's MVP after leading the Panthers to a 17-1 record as the league's highest-scoring team. Newton threw for 3,837 yards with 35 touchdowns and ran for 636 yards and 10 scores during the regular season.

The Broncos had the NFL's No. 1 defense and led the league in sacks. While Newton was sacked 33 times during the regular season, the Broncos know bringing him down Sunday won't be easy.

"If I sack him, that counts as two because he's just that hard to take down," Denver's 6-4, 258-pound pass rusher DeMarcus Ware said of the 6-5, 245-pound quarterback. "He's a phenomenal player. He's as big as me. He's a beast."

Even Broncos quarterback Peyton Manning lauded the Panthers quarterback, saying Newton's "passion and enthusiasm for the game are great football."

"There's no doubt in my mind he's going to be the MVP," Manning said. "What he's done in a short time as an NFL quarterback, he's been awesome. He's been a great passer, a great runner, a great leader. You don't go 17-1 as a starting quarterback without being awesome."

MORE: Why Manning should thank Newton | Newton vs. hypocrisy

The last time the Broncos were in the Super Bowl, they were the NFL's highest scoring team and were shut down by the league's No. 1 defense as the Seahawks rolled to a 43-8 victory two years ago. Miller didn't play in that game and obviously is hoping for a different result Sunday.

As for Newton's loud, striped gold pants he wore Sunday, Miller doesn't have an issue with them.

"When you're Superman, you can wear whatever you want," he said.

Miller and the Broncos might want to bring some Kryptonite to Levi's Stadium on Sunday.

results.title: Super Bowl Media Day 2016: Live Reaction, Interviews and Highlights for Panthers
results.body:
It's Super Bowl week!

The AFC champion Denver Broncos and NFC champion Carolina Panthers have made their way to Santa Clara, California, site of the 50th incarnation of the biggest event in sports.

And with them...madness.

That madness takes on a different form in 2016. Gone is the mayhem of Media Day on Tuesday, replaced with Super Bowl Opening Night the evening before.

Otherwise known as more primetime programming for the NFL Network.

My colleague Ty Schalter has a look at all things Broncos Monday night. Want to know what Peyton Manning had to say? Whether he'll use the plays the guy in the gold superhero suit gave him? (No really, it happened.) Then check Ty's breakdown out.

But if it's Cam Newton, Josh Norman, Kawann Short and the Panthers you want to know about you've come to the right place.

Who said what? Who wore what? What was the most inane question asked?

For answers to those questions and more set your mouse to the side, grab a seat and some nachos and get comfy.

Because here we care a lotta about Carolina.

OK. That was uncalled for.

Load More Posts

results.title: LOOK: Wade Phillips rocks Aqib Talib's bling to Super Bowl Opening Night
results.body:
Youth is surging through the Denver Broncos locker room right now, taking an effect both on and off the field.

On Sunday, prior to the Broncos flight out to San Jose, 39-year-old Peyton Manning was caught wearing some intense bling, but he's not the only "old guy" rocking ice for the Denver Broncos; Wade Phillips grabbed a necklace of his own, too.

And of course, being the Twitter maven that he is, Phillips was quick to respond.

Come on ... who told him to say that? There's no way a 68-year-old is saying "drippin" without some 20 year old whispering it in his ear.

Nonetheless, another classic from "Son Of Bum."

As we wrote on Monday, Phillips is one of the three Broncos you need to be keeping your eyes on all week, and he's quickly proving why.

Let's hope all the Broncos are rocking the ice and "drippin" Sunday night!

results.title: Peyton Manning remains mum on retirement, backs Cam for MVP
results.body:
21 CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Peyton Manning had no interest in making any announcement Monday about his future plans to a throng of media on Super Bowl Opening Night.

The Denver Broncos quarterback once again stiff-armed questions about whether he plans to retire after Super Bowl 50.

"I don't know the answer to that," Manning said when asked about whether he would be playing his final game.

NFL Films cameras captured Manning telling Bill Belichick after the AFC Championship Game "this might be my last rodeo." The quarterback acknowledged his comments while still giving himself some wiggle room.

"What I said was true: This could be it. ... Doesn't mean it will be it," Manning said.

Manning added that he was just trying to take in the moment as he entered his fourth Super Bowl in pursuit of his second title.

"Seeing other people enjoying the moment reminds me I need to be enjoying this as well," Manning said.

The five-time MVP also backed Super Bowl opponent and Carolina Panthers quarterback Cam Newton for this year's award.

"He's just had this incredible year," Manning said. "No doubt in my mind he'll win the MVP. He's been awesome - that's the best word I can think of."

Manning also held firm on his stance regarding an Al Jazeera America report alleging HGH shipments were delivered to his house in his wife's name, an accusation the NFL is currently investigating. He called the report "a complete farce, a fabrication."

"Like I said in December, I welcome it," Manning said of the investigation. "I respect the rules of the game. They're very important to me. And I welcome it, because I know what they're going to find: a big, fat no."

results.title: What to watch for as Super Bowl week kicks off
results.body:
SAN FRANCISCO -- The Super Bowl is back in California for the first time in 13 years, and the 50th battle for the Lombardi Trophy offers a dynamic matchup between the Panthers and Broncos.

Both teams arrived last night, and the week of festivities begin tonight with the first primetime edition of Super Bowl Media Day.

As always, there is no shortage of storylines in the lead-up to Sunday's game at Levi's Stadium in Santa Clara, Calif.

The Panthers and Broncos play an old-school brand of physical, intimidating football, and Panthers quarterback Cam Newton's rapid ascension yields a new-school twist.

Newton will almost certainly win the MVP, which means he'll have a chance to join Bart Starr, Terry Bradshaw, Joe Montana, Emmitt Smith, Steve Young and Kurt Warner as the seventh player in history to double up as the Super Bowl MVP.

From start to (possibly) finish, this has been the year of Newton and the Panthers, and the quarterback has legitimized himself as one of the most dominant offensive forces in the league. That's been made all the more impressive by the relative lack of big-name weapons around him, as wide receiver Steve Smith left in 2014, running back DeAngelo Williams departed in 2015 and wide receiver Kelvin Benjamin tore his ACL in August.

But Newton led the Panthers to 14 consecutive regular-season wins and 17 victories in 18 games to this point. And he has completed 59.7 percent of his passes for 3,837 yards, 35 touchdowns and just 10 interceptions while running 132 times for 636 yards and 10 scores.

The 6-foot-5, 245-pounder is a menace on third down, too, with 13 touchdowns (second most in the NFL) and a league-high 25 conversions on the ground (more than twice as many as all but four players).

However, Newton's on-field brilliance has been met with widespread criticism from the "what are we supposed to tell the children?" crowd, who can't understand that football is meant to also be fun.

Granted, the dab is insufferable, but there isn't a defense on the planet that can make him stop. Unfortunately, during a week like this, that storyline will get extra airtime from the entertainment media.

Old man Peyton

Broncos quarterback Peyton Manning told Bill Belichick after the AFC Championship Game this might be his "last rodeo," so with a win, he has a chance to go out on top like his boss, John Elway.

At this point, Manning's arm strength resembles Archie's more than his own, but his supporting cast, both offensively and defensively, is about as strong as it's ever been in his 18th season. Manning's Super Bowl history is checkered, but he could join his brother, Eli, and become the 12th quarterback to win a pair of Super Bowls.

But in Manning's two losses, he threw a pick-6 on a decisive drive against the Saints in 2009 and was embarrassed by the Seahawks in 2013, which was tied for the third most lopsided Super Bowl in history. Elway knows that feeling, too.

Oh, and there's the HGH storyline. The NFL has announced it's investigating Manning's alleged receipt of an HGH delivery in 2011, while the 39-year-old has denied ever using the PED in the fallout of the Al Jazeera report. That subplot has been largely swept under the rug over the last month, but Manning can't hide from the allegations during four consecutive days at a podium this week.

Roger that

Some 367 days ago, Roger Goodell claimed that he's available to the media every day of the year. In a conservative estimate, Goodell has fallen short of that by about 350 interviews, but he gets his next chance Friday to stand before the masses.

Deflategate will remain on the table, now and forever, as well as the league's apparent investigation into Manning's wife's HGH shipments. The "Concussion" movie will likely be addressed. It also seems fair to inquire about Greg Hardy's tone deaf remarks in the aftermath of his suspension.

But remember last year? Goodell was asked 28 questions, but only one Boston media member was called upon when droves wanted answers about Deflategate. Goodell's representatives instead doled out microphones to those who asked questions about the NFL's improved technology and the carrot it continues to dangle in front of the London audience. And this was when Goodell wasn't yucking it up with a junior reporter about their Play 60 mission.

So yeah, everyone would love to hear Goodell give genuine, informative responses about the league's shortcomings, but the reality is he'll probably spent the better portion of 45 minutes talking about how he and the league brought football back into the Los Angeles market.

And don't forget the game

Ah yes, the game. The Panthers and Broncos try to kick in their opponents' organs for 60 minutes, and the Panthers' offense likes to get nasty, too. If you like to watch teams line up with the intention of beating the heck out of one another, this is the week for you.

This is a pretty cool week for 33-year-old pass rushers Jared Allen (Panthers) and Demarcus Ware (Broncos), who are making their first trips to the Super Bowl.

Keep an eye on a couple local angles. Panthers linebacker Luke Kuechly, a Boston College product, signed a five-year, $62 million contract extension this season. Kuechly, 24, is younger than both Dont'a Hightower, 25, and Jamie Collins, 26, but they'll be arguing for contracts in that range in the next year.

Speaking of money, Panthers cornerback Josh Norman may very well be the best at the position, and he's scheduled to be a free agent in March. Norman and Broncos receiver Emmanuel Sanders will have the best battle on the perimeter in the game.

Broncos cornerback Aqib Talib spent a year and a half with the Patriots. Former Pats second-round pick Ras-I Dowling could potentially play the role of Talib on the Panthers' practice squad.

results.title: Three Denver Broncos you need to keep your eye on during Super Bowl week
results.body:
The Super Bowl is much more than just a championship event; it's a week-long extravaganza.

There's media day (or, as it's now being called, Super Bowl Opening Night), the countless parties, in-depth interviews, hot takes, radio row and, of course, the Super Bowl. Take your eyes off Twitter for one moment, and you'll miss a firestorm of storylines. Forget to tune into SportsCenter, and a heartbreaking story of perseverance and triumph may slip past your radar.

As fans, especially as Broncos fans, this whole week is a culmination of years' worth of support and dedication. It's a celebration, really. And the actual Super Bowl is the gigantic, franchise-defining cherry on top of our Broncos cake.

So enjoy every bit of this week, because moments like these don't come around often.

And with that said, here are three Broncos you need to be keeping an especially close eye on all week.

Peyton Manning may not be the most important person on this Denver Broncos team, but this is Peyton Manning's Super Bowl. Like it or not, this is a legacy-defining moment for one of the game's greatest quarterbacks. Even if he throws for 100 yards and an interception, he will be dubbed a hero in a Broncos win.

Plus, more likely than not, this will be the last game No. 18 every plays in the NFL; that's some heavy stuff.

The media will be flocking around The Sheriff all week, and I'm sure he'll have plenty to say, even if it is a little shielded. As we've seen over the last few months, but especially over the last few weeks, Manning is more emotional than ever. The fact that he's walking around Sports Authority field with his family, taking pictures and enjoying the moment tells us something: He's very cognizant of the moment he's in.

If this is Manning's last ride, he's not going to let it go to waste. Neither will the media.

results.title: Carolina Panthers vs. Denver Broncos Super Bowl Betting Odds and News Update
results.body:
With Super Bowl week finally upon us, the big question bettors want to know is, when is the right time to wager on the favored Carolina Panthers (17-1) or the underdog Denver Broncos (14-4)?

Carolina had hit as high as a six-point favorite in the big game at sportsbooks monitored by Odds Shark as of late Monday. Some books opened the Panthers as 3.5-point chalk, but that number quickly disappeared after they steamrolled the Arizona Cardinals 49-15 in the NFC Championship Game.

Even though the best time to wager on Carolina has more than likely passed, Denver backers are still patiently waiting for the perfect opportunity to bet on the underdog.

Whether or not the Super Bowl 50 line hits the magic number of seven points remains to be seen, with much of the betting action in Las Vegas taking place late in the week.

Getting six points with the Broncos might be as good as it gets, and many books still have them at that number.

This is also true with the moneyline, which involves simply wagering on the team you think will win Super Bowl 50. The best +200 price (bet $100 to win $200) you can get on Denver right now will probably not last much longer either unless money on the Panthers pours in to push the point spread to seven.

However, bettors who like the under to cash in what they think will be a defensive battle might want to wait as long as possible. The total opened as low as 44 points and is now as high as 46 points, and the public generally wagers on the over.

The Broncos bring the league's top-ranked defense into Super Bowl 50, and their best chance to win may be in a low-scoring game. Carolina's lone setback of the season was a 20-13 road loss to the Atlanta Falcons in Week 16. In the past five games for the Panthers, that is the only under that has cashed in.

Taking Denver and the under together will be a popular corresponding parlay for many, as will Carolina and the over. But Peyton Manning's ability to keep the Broncos competitive in a high-scoring affair and possibly pull off the upset in what could be his final game before he retires would spoil both possibilities.

results.title: Broncos' bus in minor crash
results.body:
Denver Broncos' Peyton Manning gets off the plane as they arrive at the Mineta San Jose International Airport for the NFL Super Bowl football game Sunday, Jan. 31, 2016, in San Jose, Calif. The Broncos play ... more

One of the Denver Broncos' team buses was involved in a minor traffic accident on Highway 101 in Mountain View on Monday afternoon.

The CHP said the bus was just north of Highway 237 when the incident occurred at 1:47 p.m.

According to a variety of tweets and social media posts, there were only "very minor injuries" although the details of those injuries and whether they involved players, coaches or Denver support staff was unclear.

DeMarcus Ware, a Denver defensive end, tweeted: "To keep the day interesting, we have a small wreck. Looks like everyone is OK though."

The Broncos play the Panthers in Super Bowl 50 at Levi's Stadium on Sunday.

results.title: Newton vs. Manning highlights Super Bowl 50 matchup - TSN
results.body:
Opposites will attract when the Carolina Panthers take on the Denver Broncos on Sunday in Super Bowl 50 at Levi's Stadium in Santa Clara, California.

The Panthers, who finished the regular season 15-1, are led by energetic quarterback Cam Newton, who in his fifth NFL season is headed to his first Super Bowl. The Broncos, meanwhile, are led by veteran quarterback Peyton Manning, who many believe will be playing his final NFL game.

You can watch Super Bowl 50 live on CTV at 6:30pm et/3:30 pt.

The two teams took very different paths along the way, but both managed to reach the Big Game.

The Panthers raced through the regular season, reaching Week 16 before finally suffering their first loss of the season in a 20-13 defeat at the hands of the already eliminated Atlanta Falcons. Newton received the lion's share of the credit for the team's record, and deservedly so, with 45 total touchdowns on the season.

Like the Panthers, the Broncos jumped out to an undefeated 7-0 start before suffering their first defeat in Week 9. However, the Broncos strong start seemingly came in spite of their star quarterback and not because of him. Manning threw just seven touchdowns in the team's first seven wins and tossed 11 interceptions. A low-point came when the Broncos needed overtime to defeat the Cleveland Browns in Week 6 as Manning turned the ball over three times. The Broncos dominant defence, however, consistently came to rescue, allowing just 16 points per game through their first seven contests. When Manning suffered a foot injury in a loss to the Kansas City Chiefs in Week 10, Brock Osweiler took over at quarterback and kept the Broncos on the playoff path with a 4-2 record. Yet, as Osweiler struggled to move the offence in Week 17 against the San Diego Chargers, it was Manning who was called in to help the team to victory and clinch the AFC's No. 1 seed.

In the postseason, the Panthers followed their regular season script of domination. The team raced to a 31-point halftime lead on the twice-defending NFC champion Seattle Seahawks in the Divisional Round before holding on for a seven-point win. One week later, in the conference championship against the Arizona Cardinals, the Panthers took a 24-7 lead into half, but this time didn't let up en route to a 49-15 blowout.

Unsurprisingly, the Broncos continued to advance in their typical nail-biting fashion. The team trailed 13-12 in the fourth quarter of the Divisional Round against the driving Pittsburgh Steelers before a fumble recovery turned the tides and allowed them to pick up a 23-16 win. Facing Manning's archrival Tom Brady in the AFC Championship, the Broncos narrowly avoided overtime thanks to a failed two-point conversion attempt by the Patriots with 12 seconds left on the game clock.

Now, the two teams' respective paths have led them to game's biggest stage with Manning out to cement his legacy, and Newton hoping to create his.

label.eng: History of the San Diego Chargers

results.title: Super Bowl 50: How the Broncos were built through the NFL Draft - CBSSports.com
results.body:
Since Peyton Manning arrived in Denver four years ago, the Broncos have consistently been a Super Bowl contender, including a trip to the big game two years ago in Super Bowl XLVIII against the Seattle Seahawks. But unlike that Super Bowl run, which was mainly orchestrated by Manning and a juggernaut offense, the Broncos are the 2015 AFC champions largely due to a suffocating defense and roster built with balance.

The Broncos have been very active in free agency, filling out the roster with cornerstone players like defensive end DeMarcus Ware, wide receiver Emmanuel Sanders and cornerback Aqib Talib. But the NFL Draft has been a critical step to the construction of the AFC champs with 22 players on the roster that Denver drafted (two more than the Panthers), including five first-round picks. Team-building is a delicate balance between free agents and draft picks and executive vice president/general manager and Broncos legend John Elway has walked the fine line well.

Another key difference in this year's Broncos team is the coaching staff as Denver and former head coach John Fox mutually agreed to part ways after last season. To create better cohesion between the coaching staff and front office, Elway hired Gary Kubiak as head coach, another familiar face as he previously served as backup quarterback (1983-91) and offensive coordinator (1995-2005) in Denver.

Following the disastrous Josh McDaniels era, Broncos owner Pat Bowlen added Elway to the front office in 2011. The move was met with skepticism as some saw the hire as a public relations move for the fans. However, it became clear very quickly that Elway was more than just a spokesman or token figure head, the Broncos were going to be built with a blueprint designed by the quarterback who won the franchise its only two Super Bowls.

Once Elway took over the day-to-day operations, he didn't insist on a complete overhaul of the player personnel department. Instead, he kept most of the football operations staff intact, adding several experienced decision-makers from the outside, including Tom Heckert, former general manager of the Cleveland Browns.

Two years ago, the Broncos advanced to the Super Bowl with a record-breaking offense led by Manning, but it was no match for the Seahawks' No. 1-ranked defense as Seattle dominated Denver in Super Bowl XLVIII, 43-8. Having a future Hall of Fame quarterback at the helm was obviously important, but, as the old adage says, defense wins championships. A few weeks after that loss, Elway committed more than $100 million in free agency to Talib, Ware and T.J. Ward and continued to focus on defensive prospects in the draft.

Yes, Elway is a former quarterback and offensive thinker by trade, but since he was hired as a member of the Broncos' front office in 2011, Denver has drafted a defensive player with their first pick in the draft each of the last five years and eight defensive players on the roster are former top-40 draft picks. Elway and his staff have also found several late-round or undrafted gems, including cornerback Chris Harris, who has made the Pro Bowl the last two years.

And the final piece to the puzzle was Wade Phillips, who was hired as defensive coordinator prior to the 2015 season. The year the Broncos lost to the Seahawks in the Super Bowl, the Denver defense finished 19th in the NFL. But that ranking improved to third in 2014 and No. 1 in 2015 under Phillips, leading the league in total yards allowed (283.1), sacks (52), forced fumbles (25) and defensive scores (four).

The core of the Broncos roster is a balance of home-grown draft picks, wise free agent signings and a few undrafted discoveries.

Manning, Ware and Talib were all signed to lucrative free agent deals on Elway's watch, along with several other important yet under-the-radar additions like linebacker Brandon Marshall and guard Louis Vasquez (both chosen as Pro Bowl alternates in 2015). Wide receiver Demaryius Thomas and offensive tackle Ryan Clady are the two core players who were on the roster prior to Elway, although Clady missed all of the 2015 seasons due to a torn ACL.

Through the draft, the Broncos have used high draft picks to find core players, including Von Miller (No. 2 overall, 2011), Derek Wolfe (No. 36 overall, 2012) and Sylvester Williams (No. 28, 2013) in the defensive front-seven. And the franchise has hit on several late round or undrafted players in the bargain bin like Harris (undrafted), Malik Jackson (No. 137 overall, 2012) and Danny Trevathan (No. 188 overall, 2012).

A player who may or may not be the future of the franchise at quarterback, Brock Osweiler proved to be a valuable member of the Broncos this season, recording a 5-2 record as a starter while Manning was out with injuries. Osweiler was drafted in the second round of the 2012 NFL Draft and will be a free agent after the Super Bowl.

Denver ranked middle of the pack in rushing this season, but are getting bang for their buck with undrafted running back C.J. Anderson (2013), who has rushed for 1,500-plus yards combined the last two seasons. Although neither Anderson nor Ronnie Hillman (No. 67 overall, 2012) are core players, they create a tandem backfield that gets the job done more times than not.

While free agent additions might be the backbone to the Broncos' roster, the team's success on draft weekend has been equally as important to Denver playing in Super Bowl 50.

Dating back to 2010, the Broncos have drafted very well with their first pick in the draft: wide receiver Demaryius Thomas (2010), linebacker Von Miller (2011), defensive tackle Derek Wolfe (2012), defensive tackle Sylvester Williams (2013), cornerback Bradley Roby (2014) and defensive end Shane Ray (2015).

With the exception of Ray, who was a nickel rusher as a rookie in 2015, the Broncos' first pick in the draft since 2010 have each been key starters on the current squad. Roby technically started only four games this past season, but his playing time is near equal to a starter due to the amount of nickel packages.

The Broncos have been far from perfect on draft weekend. They swung and missed on running back Montee Ball (No. 58 overall, 2013) and wide receiver Cody Latimer (No. 56, 2014) has taken longer than expected to develop. But Elway and his staff deserve credit for their work through the draft, especially considering they haven't drafted in the top-20 picks since 2011.

Elway was a Super Bowl-winning quarterback on the field and he might be a Super Bowl-winning executive off the field if the Broncos can pull the upset over the Panthers in Super Bowl 50. And if that happens, his accomplishments as a general manager will have been earned through hard work, preparation and talent -- just like his accomplishments as a quarterback.

"Really, what I was drawing off and have been drawing off, is my experience in my career," Elway said. "When we won those two Super Bowls, what was the formula? The formula was to play good defense, and offensively, it was about running the ball."

Some will say that it doesn't take talent to open a checkbook and write down numbers and that would be correct. However, Elway has been more than an ATM or figure head -- he has had a plan since the day he took office. And while it hasn't always been pretty, that plan has the Broncos planning for the ultimate prize on Super Bowl Sunday.

results.title: Denver Broncos take first look at Stanford to get acclimated
results.body:
SAN FRANCISCO, Calif. -- The Denver Broncos took a little field trip Monday as the team headed to Stanford University to take a look at what will be their practice home for the week leading up to Super Bowl 50.

The Broncos will have their first full practice of the week Wednesday as they stick to a schedule that is similar to what they use during the regular season. But coach Gary Kubiak took the team over to Stanford on Monday for a quick trip just so Wednesday wouldn't be the first time the players had been to the practice field.

Team officials described it as a "get acclimated" type of visit, with only some light work to go with their meetings.

And call it a lesson learned, but one significant difference between the team's practices of late, according to several Broncos players, and the last time the team was in the Super Bowl -- to close out the 2013 season -- was the Broncos have made it a point to crank up the noise at practice.

On the Broncos' first play from scrimmage in Super Bowl XLVIII, center Manny Ramirez couldn't hear the cadence from Peyton Manning and snapped the ball unexpectedly. The ball sailed past Manning's head, resulted in a safety and set the tone for what became a 35-point loss to the Seattle Seahawks.

Kubiak had the Broncos' practice with noise last week at the Broncos' facility and said he would do the same at Stanford in the week to come. Kubiak said Manning had "mentioned" the play from Super Bowl XLVIII when the team started its preparations.

"We're practicing with noise," Kubiak said earlier this week. "[The crowd] should be split right down the middle. I assume that's the way it is ... so we took the approach this week to practice with noise."

The Broncos installed much of the game plan before they left Denver on Sunday, so this week's practices will be more about refining what they've already worked on and to make any adjustments they feel are necessary as the week progresses.

"We feel like we're ready to go," linebacker Brandon Marshall said. "We'll get ourselves right, the coaches will have us ready to go."

results.title: Inside Conditions...Fanfare for the common man
results.body:
Hey by the time that you read this article, Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump will have won the Iowa caucuses' (maybe). One thousand questions will have been asked about the arm strength of the Denver Broncos quarterback Peyton Manning, (probably). And last but not least, the Broncos defense will not have enough kryptonite to weaken the super athletic powers of the Carolina Panthers superstar quarterback, halfback, fullback, Cam Newton, (more than likely).

Racial purist's disguised as football fans can drink "haterade' until their stomachs burst but the Denver Broncos are nearing their final destination as far as the 2015 season is concerned.

The Broncos are not destined to be in the winner's circle when the clock expires on February 7, 2016 at the end of Super Bowl 50.

If the Broncos win I will stand outside of my downtown Pittsburgh office clothed only in a sheet and will allow the photo to be seen by all of my readers. If the Panthers prevail, the first reader to send email me, will have the opportunity to take me out to lunch and pick my brain about sports and about anything else, (I will leave the tip, any place is good even McDonald's).

If Cam Newton blows it for me I will curse him to be forced to compete with deflated footballs forever.

I am from the old school. I loved it when I saw the video of Seattle Seahawks All-Pro cornerback Richard Sherman dropping an RKO on fellow All-Pro Green Bay Packers linebacker Clay Matthews during last Sunday's NFL Pro-Bowl game.

With all of the long blonde hair, good ole boy versus the dreadlock thug social values that some people are currently trying to use to divide America as well sports, it is refreshing to see two grown famous rich athletes, allowing the little boy in them to come out.

Forget about dividing and conquering. How about unifying and conquering?

Sherman and Matthews may have started a trend of not asking the asinine question; "can't we all just get along?" as opposed to just getting along.

Some of the Twitter "sloggers" seem to be sinking in quicksand mixed with poop. They want to see White versus Black, Hispanic, Asian, Indians, and Jews: just White against everybody else.

Let's quit trying to dominate, and attempt to reciprocate. May we begin accepting each other's "trains of thought," as opposed to insisting that everyone else mirrors one set of ideas and theories?

For God sake, football is just a sport! I have not heard any breaking stories concerning any life preserving cures for cancer, diabetes, heart disease or any other health or life threatening disease that emerged from the 2015 NFL Pro-Bowl.

I am also certain that at the end of Super Bowl 50, there will be no press conferences held other than to say which team lost and which team won, and why.

So to all of you "race-baiting" naysayers out there hiding behind the internet all I have to say is this; we Americans may lose a few battles but when the smoke clears, whether it is on the football fields or the killing fields, we will stand toe to toe and the melody that we celebrate at the end of the day will not be "Taps" but will always be Aaron Copeland's; "Fanfare for the Common Man."

Aubrey Bruce can be reached at: abruce@newpittsburghcourier.com or 412.583.6741
